choices.text: Continue

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: It’s early morning. Your phone buzzes louder than your alarm. It’s a long message from your ex — written at 3:12 AM.

choices.label: Read the message immediately.
choices.text: You unlock your phone and open the message, heart already racing.

choices.label: Silence the phone and give yourself five minutes.
choices.text: You flip the phone over and focus on breathing. The message can wait a moment.

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text: The message is a mix of panic and blame: “I can’t sleep, I’m doing EVERYTHING for our child. You don’t understand how hard this is. Maybe I should just keep her full time.”

choices.label: Reply with reassurance and boundaries.
choices.text: You type: “I hear that you’re overwhelmed. We’re both doing our best. Let’s talk about changes to the schedule with a mediator, not at 3 AM.”

choices.label: React defensively.
choices.text: You snap back: “You’re not the only one who’s tired. Threatening custody changes in the middle of the night is not okay.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You stare at the screen, thinking of your child still asleep, unaware of these late-night storms.

choices.label: Focus on what you can control today.
choices.text: You decide to anchor your day: breakfast, school drop-off, work. One step at a time.

choices.label: Spiral into worst-case scenarios.
choices.text: You imagine court battles, custody fights, the worst of everything, all before breakfast.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: The day is just beginning, but the emotional weather is already stormy.

choices.label: Move to Act 2 – Planning the Conversation.
choices.text: You decide this can’t stay in endless text threads. It needs structure.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Later that day, you sit at the kitchen table with a notepad. You know that unstructured talks often end in chaos.

choices.label: Suggest meeting with a mediator.
choices.text: You draft: “I think it would help if we talked about schedules with a neutral mediator. Would you be open to that?”

choices.label: Try to handle it alone, one-on-one.
choices.text: You decide to invite them for coffee to “talk it out”, just the two of you.

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text: Their reply pings back: “I don’t need a stranger telling me how to raise my kid.”

choices.label: Normalize support.
choices.text: You write: “Mediators aren’t there to judge, just to help us communicate when things feel intense.”

choices.label: Back off and postpone.
choices.text: You decide not to push it further today and let the topic rest.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You remind yourself that bipolar disorder adds another layer to every conversation: energy spikes, crashes, and sensitivity to perceived criticism.

choices.label: Plan your next steps around stability, not reaction.
choices.text: You make a note to only suggest big changes during more stable periods, not right after crises.

choices.label: Continue to react to the latest mood.
choices.text: You resign yourself to “seeing how they are that day” and adjusting on the fly.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You put the pen down. The situation is still complex, but at least you have a plan that doesn’t rely solely on midnight messages.

choices.label: Continue to Act 3 – The Crash After the Storm.
choices.text: You decide to pay attention to how the next days unfold, knowing the cycle hasn’t finished yet.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scenario here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Two days pass with no messages from your ex. No 3 AM paragraphs. No spiraling accusations. No schedule threats.

Just silence.

You find yourself checking your phone more than usual — half-relieved, half-anxious. Your child asks at breakfast, "Is everything okay with Mom/Dad?" in the soft voice they use when they’ve been sensing something.

This quiet feels less like calm and more like the air right after a storm — heavy, unstable, waiting.

choices.label: Keep things stable and predictable at home.
choices.text: You smile gently. "Yep, everything’s okay. Let’s get ready for school."

choices.label: Try contacting your ex to check in.
choices.text: You text: "Haven’t heard from you — are you doing alright?"

choices.label: Vent internally and shut down emotionally.
choices.text: You mutter, "I don’t know. Ask them," and focus on your coffee.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
At school drop-off, you catch a glimpse of your ex across the street. Their posture is different — shoulders rounded, eyes tired. No makeup, no energy, no spark.

When they see you, they look away quickly.

Your child notices and hesitates, gripping your sleeve. "Did I do something wrong?" they whisper.

You feel the weight of two worlds again: your child’s confusion, your ex-partner’s crash, and your own responsibility not to mix the two.

choices.label: Give a child-friendly explanation without blaming.
choices.text: You kneel to their level. "No, sweetheart. Grown-ups have big feelings sometimes. It’s not your fault."

choices.label: Over-explain the bipolar cycle to the child.
choices.text: You launch into a complicated explanation about moods, chemicals, and diagnoses your child is too young to fully grasp.

choices.label: Say nothing and rush the drop-off.
choices.text: "Come on, we’re late," you say, buckling them in faster and changing the subject.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
That evening, a short message arrives from your ex:

"Sorry for everything. I’m exhausted. I can’t talk about the schedule right now."

No accusations. No threats. Just fatigue.

Under the text, you imagine the unsent drafts they typed and deleted — hints of inner turmoil. This is the bipolar downswing: fragile, sensitive, easily overwhelmed.

Your next move matters.

choices.label: Respond gently and keep the scope small.
choices.text: You type: "Thanks for letting me know. Rest for now. We’ll talk when you have more energy."

choices.label: Push for the schedule conversation anyway.
choices.text: You reply: "We still need to fix the custody stuff. When can we talk?"

choices.label: Say nothing, letting the thread drop.
choices.text: You close the app without replying, choosing silence over engagement.

nodes.speaker: Child
nodes.text:
At bedtime, your child curls up closer than usual.

"Are you and Mom/Dad mad at each other again?" Their voice wobbles.

You suddenly realize how tuned in they are — even to the parts you try to hide. They don’t know about mood episodes, sleep deprivation, or dysregulated 3 AM texting. They only know the emotional weather.

choices.label: Offer clarity and security.
choices.text: "We’re figuring things out, and you’re safe. Always," you say, holding them a little tighter.

choices.label: Say "It’s complicated" without giving reassurance.
choices.text: "It’s adult stuff… complicated adult stuff," you answer, staring at the ceiling.

choices.label: Unload your frustration in front of them.
choices.text: "I honestly don’t know what’s going on with your other parent anymore," you sigh, the words heavier than you intended.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
The storm didn’t vanish — it just inverted, from loud chaos to quiet collapse.

Bipolar cycles often do this: one parent on the floor, one parent holding the structure, a child trying to make sense of the shifting gravity.

Tonight, your home is steady. But you know the bigger work is ahead: finding a way to co-parent without riding every spike and crash.

Tomorrow will need structure, support, and maybe a third voice in the room.

choices.label: Continue to Act 4 – Stability Planning with a Mediator.
choices.text: You decide it’s time to bring a neutral professional into the conversation.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scenario here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Two days later, you and your ex meet with a neutral mediator. It’s a small office — soft chairs, a box of tissues on the table, a whiteboard with markers in calming colors.

The mediator begins: "Let’s focus today on stability. What helps each of you stay grounded? And what helps your child feel safe?"

Your ex sits slouched in the chair, quieter than usual, eyes tired but receptive.

choices.label: Start with concrete needs: predictable schedules and communication windows.
choices.text: You say, "For me, having clear times to talk and a predictable weekly schedule really helps."

choices.label: Start with emotional processing.
choices.text: You admit, "I felt scared by the 3 AM messages. I don’t want to keep having conversations in crisis mode."

choices.label: Start with blaming statements about their instability.
choices.text: You lead with, "We’re only here because you keep losing control."

nodes.speaker: Mediator
nodes.text:
The mediator writes "Boundaries" at the top of the whiteboard.

"Both of you deserve communication that feels safe and respectful," they say. "What boundaries would help reduce escalation?"

Your ex rubs their forehead, then quietly says, "I know I get intense when I don’t sleep. I don’t want to scare anyone." It’s the first moment of ownership you’ve heard in a while.

choices.label: Propose time-of-day communication limits.
choices.text: You suggest, "No major discussions after 9 PM, and no heavy topics during known crisis times."

choices.label: Propose content boundaries.
choices.text: You add, "No threats, no accusations, and no last-minute schedule changes by text."

choices.label: Refuse boundaries because they won’t follow them anyway.
choices.text: You cross your arms. "Honestly, I don’t see the point. You’re not going to stick to any of this."

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
The mediator draws a second heading: "Crisis Plan."

"If a manic or depressive episode hits," they ask, "what happens next? What’s the backup plan for the child?"

Your ex stares at their hands, then nods slowly. This is the hard part.

choices.label: Suggest a simple, non-shaming protocol.
choices.text: "If either of us is overwhelmed, we pause the conversation and use the mediator or a hotline instead of involving our child," you propose.

choices.label: Suggest switching custody during crisis days.
choices.text: "If one of us has a really bad day, the other automatically takes over for 24 hours," you offer.

choices.label: Reject the idea of a crisis plan.
choices.text: "I don’t want a crisis plan. It just makes it feel like you’re unreliable all the time," you say.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
After an hour, the whiteboard has turned into an early blueprint:
- communication limits
- tone boundaries
- crisis protocol
- how to shield the child
- how to request support
- what’s off-limits in front of the child
- what happens on unstable days
- when to revisit the plan

Your ex reads the list silently, then says softly, "I can try this. I don’t want our kid to feel scared." For the first time in a long time, you feel both of you leaning in the same direction — even if shakily.

choices.label: Affirm the shared intention.
choices.text: "I want that too," you say. "We’re building something steadier."

choices.label: Stay neutral and focus on logistics only.
choices.text: "Okay. Let’s see how it goes," you reply, keeping your tone even.

choices.label: Question their ability to follow through.
choices.text: "We’ll see if you actually stick to it," you say before you can stop yourself.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Co-parenting with bipolar disorder will never be perfectly smooth — but smooth was never the goal.

Predictable. Honest. Child-safe. These are good goals.

The mediator wipes the board clean but sends you both a copy of the notes. For the first time in weeks, you leave a conversation feeling like you’re walking toward something instead of running from a fire.

choices.label: Continue to Act 5 – Repairing Trust & Long-Term Care.
choices.text: You take a breath and commit to trying this new structure.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scenario here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
A week after the mediation session, the emotional weather has settled. No 3 AM messages. No panicked threats. No silent days.

Just steady mornings.

Your child is eating cereal, humming softly. You realize how much their nervous system mirrors yours — when you’re steadier, they’re steadier.

Then your phone buzzes. It’s your ex: "Can we talk for five minutes today? Not an emergency." Your stomach tightens anyway.

choices.label: Agree, but set a structure.
choices.text: You reply: "Yes — let’s talk after school pickup for 5 minutes. Agenda only: schedule."

choices.label: Agree vaguely, with no limits.
choices.text: You answer: "Sure, just call whenever."

choices.label: Say no and avoid the conversation entirely.
choices.text: You type back: "Not today," and put your phone face down.

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text:
When you connect later, their voice is quieter, more even.

"I just… wanted to say thanks," they begin. "For not firing back when I was spiraling. For meeting with the mediator. For making that crisis plan. It helps."

You hear genuine accountability — rare, but meaningful. Your child sits nearby drawing, half-listening with their sensitive radar.

choices.label: Acknowledge the effort and reinforce stability.
choices.text: "I appreciate you saying that. And the plan helps all of us," you answer.

choices.label: Stay neutral and keep distance.
choices.text: "Okay. Thanks," you say, keeping your tone flat.

choices.label: Bring up old hurt immediately.
choices.text: "Well, the damage is still there. An apology isn’t enough," you respond.

nodes.speaker: Child
nodes.text:
Later that evening, your child crawls onto the couch beside you with their favorite blanket.

"Mom/Dad called today," they say. "They sounded… nicer. Does that mean things are okay now?"

Their eyes are wide — children track safety the way sailors track tides. They’re not asking about bipolar disorder. They’re asking if their world is becoming predictable again.

choices.label: Give a balanced, hopeful truth.
choices.text: "We’re working on things," you say. "Some days are hard, some days are easier — but you’re always safe."

choices.label: Give an overly rosy answer.
choices.text: "Yep! Everything is perfect now!" you say brightly.

choices.label: Unload adult frustration.
choices.text: "I don’t know," you sigh. "Your other parent is unpredictable."

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Later, after your child is asleep, you revisit the pages from the mediator:
- crisis boundaries
- communication windows
- tone rules
- safety checks
- child shields
- scheduled reviews

Something in you softens. Not because everything is magically fixed, but because the future doesn’t feel like a constant emergency anymore.

Your ex sends one more message: "Let’s review the plan monthly? I want to keep this steady."

choices.label: Agree and reinforce the ritual.
choices.text: "Monthly works," you reply. "Predictability helps all of us."

choices.label: Agree but leave it vague.
choices.text: "Sure. Maybe monthly. We’ll see," you type back.

choices.label: Reject the idea out of old resentment.
choices.text: "I don’t want regular check-ins. We’re done talking," you write, then hesitate before hitting send.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
There is no cure for bipolar disorder, and no perfect script for co-parenting alongside it.

But there is rhythm. There is structure. There is repair.

For your child, what matters most isn’t perfection, but predictability, clarity, and adults who try again even after hard days.

You close the plan, turn off the light, and allow yourself a moment of quiet pride — not because everything is easy, but because you’re building something that can survive the storms.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You end the scenario here and step back to the main menu.

choices.label: Replay from the beginning.
choices.text: You decide to revisit the story from the first morning message.
